Posts.Content: Nov 3, 2015 04:26AM cjafarm wrote: I didn't get "results" at the diagnostic and ultrasound, but I wouldn't mind playing poker with the radiologist. Her face told me it was highly probable that the area was cancer. And she asked the tech to ultrasound the lymph nodes on that side. They made the arrangements for the biopsy while I got changed.
Posts.Title: Will I get results from my mammo & US at appt? Amybeth68 LisaAlissa

Posts.Content: Oct 28, 2015 04:01PM - edited Oct 28, 2015 04:02PM by cjafarm What could be the scariest part of a core biopsy is the sound of the core biopsy needle. It is spring loaded and can make a startling noise. Ask your radiologist to demonstrate it for you so you know what the sound is. I have had numerous biopsies and don't recall any of them being painful. But I do bruise easily and always have an ugly bruise for about a week. My last biopsy was on a Friday and I received my call on Tuesday that it was cancerous. She didn't have the details but when I met with the breast surgeon the next day he had the full pathology report for me. Having your procedure on a Monday may help get your results that week.  Good luck.
Posts.Title: Upcoming Core Biopsy etnasgrl cjafarm

Posts.Content: Oct 28, 2015 05:35PM cjafarm wrote: Check directly with your insurance company. Ask how the radiologist is billing. Mine was billed as an office visit and I paid $80 of the $1700
Posts.Title: Upcoming Core Biopsy etnasgrl cjafarm

Posts.Content: Oct 29, 2015 04:22PM cjafarm wrote: Go to the breast surgeon. For years I would have my mammogram and the radiologist would look at them, then I would walk down the hall to the surgeon and have him look them over. The two would talk and tell me what they saw or didn't see. It was very reassuring to leave and know what was going on.

Posts.Title: November 2015 Surgeries Thread? Girl53 Live4them

Posts.Content: Nov 25, 2015 11:22AM - edited Nov 30, 2015 07:45PM by cjafarm I always regretted getting the letter reminding me that it was time for my annual mammogram but I knew that it was one of those things that needed to be done. My bs told me today that I am breast cancer free. I will do hormone therapy and hope to stay cancer free. This reassured me that the bilateral mastectomy w/out reconstruction was right for me. My thoughts are with everyone and their families facing not only breast cancer but all cancers (Lost my mom and dad to cancer.) We must continue to encourage others to have those mammograms and follow their instincts and to catch this ugly beast early
Posts.Title: November 2015 Surgeries Thread? Girl53 Live4them

Posts.Content: Nov 9, 2015 05:41PM - edited Nov 9, 2015 05:45PM by cjafarm lovingisliving and new__me My surgery was Friday and I had the dye injected for sentinel lymph nodes detection. My injection did sting a little and was put in at what I would call the 11:00 area. I have learned to close my eyes and encourage myself to relax and breath before any type of procedure. It helps me immensely I went from that room directly to surgery because of a change in schedule. In fact my surgeon pushed my wheel chair to the OR and talked football with me the whole way. I was very lucky in that no cancer had moved to the lymph nodes.  Best wishes to both of you.
Posts.Title: November 2015 Surgeries Thread? Girl53 Live4them

Posts.Content: Dec 3, 2015 01:48AM cjafarm wrote: Tikkasmom, I also had the double mastectomy for a very small cancer. Initially the BS wanted to do lumpectomy and radiation. But after discussing my history with the other breast we mutually decided for the double. I also was adament about not wanting radiation. Margins and lymph nodes were clean. Will meet tomorrow with MO to discuss hormone inhibitor. I am post menopausal. Will let you know what drug he recommends.
Posts.Title: November 2015 Surgeries Thread? Girl53 Live4them

Posts.Content: Nov 2, 2015 04:31PM cjafarm wrote: Ladies, Don't be afraid to ask for something to help take the edge off during these times of waiting. My doctor called me today to see how I was doing and asked if I still had Xanax on hand (see prescribed it to me when my dad had cancer). I said yes that I had been taking it lately. Her advice was to take it twice a day instead of just once, when I felt I needed it. It was nice to know that it is available to me.
